articles.headline: ‘Dangerous Moment’ for Europe, as Fear and Resentment Grow
articles.snippet: The strike against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo seems certain to accelerate the growth of anti-Islamic sentiment in Europe.
articles.abstract: The strike against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo seems certain to accelerate the growth of anti-Islamic sentiment in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sophisticated, military-style strike Wednesday on a French newspaper known for satirizing Islam staggered a continent already seething with anti-immigrant sentiments in some quarters, feeding far-right nationalist parties like France’s National Front.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: F.B.I. Says Little Doubt North Korea Hit Sony
articles.snippet: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
articles.abstract: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I.’s director, James B. Comey, said on Wednesday that the United States had concluded that North Korea was behind the destructive attacks on Sony Pictures partly because the hackers failed to mask their location when they broke into the company’s servers.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Proud to Offend, Charlie Hebdo Carries Torch of Political Provocation
articles.snippet: The struggling satirical paper was once firebombed, but it continued to amuse and horrify, taking pride in offending one and all.
articles.abstract: The struggling satirical paper was once firebombed, but it continued to amuse and horrify, taking pride in offending one and all.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 2012, when Charlie Hebdo editors defied the government’s advice and published crude caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad naked and in sexual poses, the French authorities shut down embassies, cultural centers and schools in about 20 countries.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Suzanne Daley

articles.headline: China Wants Taxes Paid by Citizens Living Afar
articles.snippet: A longtime law, widely ignored, requires individuals and companies to pay domestic taxes on income earned outside the country.
articles.abstract: A longtime law, widely ignored, requires individuals and companies to pay domestic taxes on income earned outside the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As Chinese individuals and companies head overseas in greater numbers, the country’s tax authorities are starting to follow.

articles.headline: Iraq Veteran, Now a West Point Professor, Seeks to Rein In Disability Pay
articles.snippet: Lt. Col. Daniel Gade is traveling the country to urge a shift toward work incentives for disabled veterans, but some find his message misguided.
articles.abstract: Lt. Col. Daniel Gade is traveling the country to urge a shift toward work incentives for disabled veterans, but some find his message misguided.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Nearly 200 sick and wounded soldiers in a gym at Fort Carson last month listened silently as Lt. Col. Daniel Gade offered a surprising warning: The disability checks designed to help troops like them after they leave the service might actually be harmful.

articles.headline: U.S. Oil Producers Cut Rigs as Price Declines
articles.snippet: Falling oil prices have prompted producers to slash the number of drilling rigs around the country.
articles.abstract: Falling oil prices have prompted producers to slash the number of drilling rigs around the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With oil prices plunging at an ever-quickening rate, producers are beginning to slash the number of drilling rigs around the country.

articles.headline: Democrats Step Up Efforts to Block Obama’s Trade Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama is facing new opposition from his own party to one of his top priorities: winning the power to negotiate international trade pacts and speed them through Congress.
articles.abstract: President Obama is facing new opposition from his own party to one of his top priorities: winning the power to negotiate international trade pacts and speed them through Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is facing opposition from fellow Democrats to one of his top priorities: winning the power to negotiate international trade agreements and speed them through Congress.

articles.headline: Recounting a Bustling Office at Charlie Hebdo, Then a ‘Vision of Horror’
articles.snippet: As witnesses recounted the massacre at the French satirical newspaper, details emerged of a routine day turned violent.
articles.abstract: As witnesses recounted the massacre at the French satirical newspaper, details emerged of a routine day turned violent.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stéphane Charbonnier was perched, as was his habit every Wednesday morning, at a U-shaped wooden table on the second floor of the light-filled Parisian offices of Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical newspaper he headed. An array of papers was spread before him.
